Students can naturally improve their Mandarin while experiencing the charm of Taiwanese culture.

cooperation.title: Cooperation Model & Role Definition
cooperation.desc: Clarifies our role in cross-border workforce collaboration and how we work with licensed Japanese employment agencies.
cooperation.category: For Japanese employment agencies and human resource partners
cooperation.alt: Japan recruitment agency cooperation overseas workforce matching
cooperation.q1: What role do you play in the overall process?
cooperation.a1: We act as a matching and coordination partner, connecting Southeast Asian sending organizations, Taiwan-based human resources, and licensed Japanese employment agencies. Our role focuses on early-stage candidate information整理, condition alignment, and partner matching. We do not conduct employment placement or statutory procedures in Japan.
cooperation.q2: Do you replace the role of Japanese employment agencies?
cooperation.a2: No. We do not conduct employment placement activities in Japan. All formal job placement, employment contracts, and residence status procedures are handled exclusively by licensed Japanese employment agencies.
cooperation.q3: What types of partners are suitable for cooperation?
cooperation.a3: Our services are suitable for Japanese employment agencies that already handle or plan to handle overseas workforce cases, as well as partners seeking to expand their options for Southeast Asian or Taiwanese talent.
cooperation.q4: Can cooperation start with a single case?
cooperation.a4: Yes. Most collaborations begin with a single case or a backup staffing need. No exclusive or long-term commitment is required.
cooperation.q5: Is it necessary to sign a long-term or exclusive agreement?
cooperation.a5: No. Cooperation is conducted on a case-by-case basis to maintain flexibility and avoid interference with existing partnerships.
cooperation.q6: Is cooperation still possible if we already work with a fixed Southeast Asian sending organization?
cooperation.a6: Yes. We often act as a secondary or backup option, supporting cases that existing sending organizations may find difficult to handle or are temporarily unable to supply.
cooperation.q7: Do you directly contact Japanese corporate clients?
cooperation.a7: This depends on the cooperation model. When cases are led by a Japanese employment agency, we participate as a backend support and coordination partner without affecting existing client relationships.
cooperation.q8: Who communicates with which parties during cooperation?
cooperation.a8: We primarily coordinate with Southeast Asian sending organizations and Taiwan-side partners. Communication with Japanese companies and formal placement processes remains led by the Japanese employment agency.
cooperation.q9: Can we exchange information first before deciding on cooperation?
cooperation.a9: Yes. We encourage initial information exchange regarding cases or candidate conditions before determining further cooperation.

resources.title: Talent Sources & Matching Scope
resources.desc: Introduces available talent sources and suitable case types for cooperation.
resources.category: For partners interested in talent sourcing flexibility
resources.alt: Southeast Asia talent Taiwan talent overseas workforce sources
resources.q1: What talent sources can you provide?
resources.a1: Our primary sources are Southeast Asian talents (such as Vietnam and Indonesia). Depending on case requirements, we can also provide Taiwanese talent as a supplementary option.
resources.q2: Are there additional introduction fees for Southeast Asian talent?
resources.a2: The Southeast Asian sending organizations we cooperate with are long-term partners of Taiwanese enterprises. Therefore, no additional introduction fees are charged to the Japanese side.
resources.q3: Are you limited to specific industries or job categories?
resources.a3: No. However, suitability for overseas talent is evaluated during the early-stage assessment based on actual job content, working conditions, and management structure.
resources.q4: Can you act as a secondary or backup talent source?
resources.a4: Yes. We frequently serve as a backup option alongside existing sending organizations, particularly for cases with special conditions or higher risk.
resources.q5: Is it possible to compare multiple nationalities or sources simultaneously?
resources.a5: Yes. We can provide recommendations across multiple talent sources based on case conditions to support comparison and decision-making.
resources.q6: Can you support situations where talent supply is unstable?
resources.a6: One of our roles is to fill supply gaps by offering alternative options when existing channels cannot provide candidates in time.
resources.q7: Do you help evaluate whether a position is suitable for overseas talent?
resources.a7: Yes. Before entering the formal placement process, we can conduct an early-stage feasibility assessment of the position.
resources.q8: Do you handle short-term or part-time-only cases?
resources.a8: Our focus is on full-time positions eligible for lawful residence status. We do not handle cases limited to part-time work or short-term internships.

scope.title: Scope of Responsibility & Post-Placement Support
scope.desc: Clarifies service boundaries and available support after placement.
scope.category: For partners focused on risk management and clear role allocation
scope.alt: Overseas workforce post-placement support cooperation scope
scope.q1: Do you assist with post-placement issues?
scope.a1: If communication or adaptation issues arise after placement, we can coordinate with sending organizations and relevant parties to provide informational support and adjustment assistance. However, we do not assume statutory management responsibilities in Japan.
scope.q2: Do you handle labor management or labor disputes?
scope.a2: No. Labor management and legal responsibilities are handled in accordance with Japanese law by the employer and licensed employment agency.
scope.q3: Do you handle visa or residence status applications?
scope.a3: No. Visa and residence status applications are handled by licensed Japanese employment agencies or certified administrative scriveners.
scope.q4: How are issues handled during cooperation?
scope.a4: Our role is to facilitate communication and coordination, ensure transparency of information, and support partners in quickly clarifying situations so that each party can respond in compliance with applicable regulations.
scope.q5: Do you provide regular follow-ups or feedback mechanisms?
scope.a5: Periodic information feedback can be arranged based on case requirements to help track talent adaptation.
scope.q6: If a worker leaves early, are you responsible for replacement?
scope.a6: Replacement arrangements depend on the contract between the Japanese employment agency and the employer. We can assist with subsequent communication and matching support.
scope.q7: Do you provide any employment outcome guarantees?
scope.a7: No. We do not provide employment outcome guarantees. Our responsibility is limited to matching and coordination support.
scope.q8: Can you help establish long-term cooperation processes?
scope.a8: Yes. Based on cooperation experience, we can assist in organizing repeatable workflows and communication frameworks.

stortText: “Formosa” is more than just a place name — it's where we began. As a Taiwan-based recruitment agency, FORMA is dedicated to bridging cultural and geographic boundaries by connecting talents from Taiwan and Asia with Japanese companies seeking global growth. We specialize in study-abroad support, language school placement, and manpower services in Japan, offering comprehensive solutions from school applications and pre-departure guidance to local support and Specified Skilled Worker job matching. At FORMA, we believe that every step across borders opens the door to new possibilities.
title_Formosa: Reflecting our Taiwanese origin, embracing diverse cultures and passion—this is the foundation of our cross-cultural mission.
title_Opportunity: We strive to create fresh opportunities for both businesses and talent, turning possibilities into tangible growth.
title_Resource: By building networks and integrating international resources, we help clients overcome cultural and regional barriers.
title_Momentum: Relentless advancement and accelerated growth fuel our core drive as we move forward together with you.
title_Alliance: Progressing hand in hand with our clients, we emphasize the power of alliances for shared success.

visa.title: Supported Japanese Visa Types
visa.subtitle: Managed by Taiwan agency, assisting Asian talent with employment and study visas in Japan

special.title: Specified Skilled Worker Visa
special.desc: Introduced by the Japanese government to address labor shortages in 12 industries including food service, construction, caregiving, agriculture, and manufacturing. Applicants must pass skill tests and have Japanese proficiency (N4 or above).
special.alt: Japan Specified Skilled Worker Visa 12 industries food construction caregiving agriculture manufacturing

engineer.title: Engineer / Specialist in Humanities / International Services Visa
engineer.desc: For professionals in engineering, IT, accounting, design, trade, and marketing. This is a long-term work visa requiring relevant education or professional experience.
engineer.alt: Japan Engineer Humanities International Services Visa IT engineering design accounting trade marketing

intern.title: Technical Intern Training
intern.desc: For young people from developing countries to learn and practice skills in Japan, usually 1-5 years. After completion, they may return home or transition to the Specified Skilled Worker visa.
intern.alt: Japan Technical Intern Training foreign talent skill learning program

foreign.title: Why Choose Foreign Talent?

employer.title: Value for Employers
employer.point1: Address labor shortages: Foreign workers fill gaps in industries such as food, construction, and caregiving.
employer.point2: Enhance skills: Professionals in IT, engineering, design, and accounting support core business operations.
employer.point3: Cultural diversity: Bring diverse backgrounds to foster innovation and global perspectives.
employer.point4: Stability & loyalty: High retention rates and strong motivation make foreign talent key assets.

jobseeker.title: Advantages for Job Seekers
jobseeker.point1: Legal & transparent: Managed by Taiwan agency, ensuring compliance and safety.
jobseeker.point2: Full support: Visa application, Japanese training, and pre-/post-arrival guidance.
jobseeker.point3: Wide options: Opportunities in labor, professional fields, study, and internships.
jobseeker.point4: Peace of mind: Formal contracts protect job seekers’ rights in Japan.
